oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Order from Brigadier General Felix Zollicoffer

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military rations ; Equipment & supplies

Zollicoffer, Felix Kirk, 1812-1862 ; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Equipment and supplies;United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Military rations; Military orders; Provisional Army of Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Order from Brigadier Genernal Felix Zollicoffer, Nashville, handwritten on a Bill of Purchase form, making arrangements, when necessary, to provide the commutation value of the rations instead of the actual rations to the Commands, July 17, 1861.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee -- Adjutant-General's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 4, Provisional Army of Tennessee Records, 1861
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: By definition, a ration is the amount of food authorized for one soldier (or animal) for one day. The Confederate government adopted the official U. S. Army ration at the start of the war, although by the spring of 1862 they had to reduce the amount because of food shortages that affected not only the military but also the entire Southern civilian population.
